142466153.review:
Prepare to embark on an extraordinary journey through a world where enchantment knows no bounds and a radiant aura of boundless optimism beckons at every turn. Like a warm, snug quilt on a chilly winter evening, this game's allure promises to whisk you away from life's worries and transport you into a realm of pure, effervescent joy. As you delve deeper into this magical experience, you'll find yourself yearning for the rest of the adventure that awaits.

The visuals are a pure delight, akin to strolling through a beautiful garden filled with the most adorable flowers you've ever seen. It's as if the developers distilled joy into pixels and sprinkled them all over Pug World. Each environment feels like a lovingly crafted diorama, complete with little details that add to the overall charm.

But what truly strikes a chord with players is the soundtrack. It's like a captivating melody that weaves its way into your heart. The music perfectly complements the game's atmosphere, making it a joyous experience from start to finish.

Now, let's talk about the pug characters. They're like a group of furry friends accompanying you on this delightful journey. Whether you prefer the speedy sprinter or the acrobatic jumper, there's a pug that suits every playstyle.

The mini-games are the hidden gems that make this adventure even more memorable. These bite-sized challenges break up the gameplay in the best way possible, offering a refreshing change of pace.

And then there's the community's contribution with custom skins. It's a sight to behold. Dressing up digital pugs could be so enjoyable! It's like attending a virtual costume party where everyone's imagination runs wild. The creativity on display is truly awe-inspiring, adding an extra layer of fun to the overall experience.

Now, if one were to nitpick, it could be said that some additional content or surprises in the levels could elevate the experience even further. While the game is undeniably charming, a little extra sprinkle of surprises could make it feel even more magical.

In summary, Turbo Pug DX is a game that exudes joy and positivity. Its unique blend of cuteness, delightful characters, and addictive gameplay will make players feel like they're floating on a cloud of happiness. It's a journey worth taking, and any player would be glad they embarked on it.

Since Turbo Pug DX is Turbo Pug with a graphical upgrade, more music and a few improvements, my review for Turbo Pug mostly applies:
[quote] Turbo Pug is an infinitely scrolling platformer where you play as a pug and aim to reach a score as high as possible. That’s pretty much all there is to this game, think of it as a slightly upgraded, pug-themed version of the dinosaur game from Google Chrome. There are a few characters to unlock and I guess getting occasionally zapped by lightning is a funny addition. In regards to gameplay, free mobile games like Subway Surfers are probably better and more convenient alternatives but if you have a particular fascination with pugs you might enjoy this game more. Usually I wouldn’t recommend paying money for a game this simple with free alternatives but since it is remarkably cheap and doesn’t pretend to be anything more than it is I’ll give it a positive review of 5/10. [/quote]
Since it is a slight visual and auditory improvement with a bit more variety in the level generation for the same price, I’ll bump it up to a 6/10.

138786136.review:
Ah, the joy of revisiting a genre that scarred me for life. "Bit Trip Runner" was my initiation into this masochistic gaming experience. After subjecting myself to its torturous challenges, I genuinely considered hammering my own fingers before even thinking about playing this kind of title again (which honestly made me wonder what motivated me to give this title a chance in the first place)

Now, let me clarify, this game is relatively forgiving. Sure, it still induces stress and frustration, but at least it won't drive you to the point of playing football with your precious gamepad

You only have one map to endure, so no gauntlet of escalating difficulty here. As time passes, the background and environment change, kinda like the thrilling ending scene of the first Megaman game. Riveting, isn't it?

Your sole purpose is to run for as long as possible, racking up those oh-so-important points. Ah, you can unlock different characters along the way, but don't get too excited; they're just different skins. Nothing special, really

The graphics, music, and sound effects do their job adequately, serving their purpose without making you claw your skin out

All in all, if you're seeking a runner game that most probably won't leave you emotionally scarred or in need of therapy, this might be a decent option. With a bit of perseverance, you can conquer all the achievements and emerge from the experience somewhat intact. Plus, the price won't put a gaping hole in your wallet

77963566.review:
[b]My playtime:[/b] 28.6h (based on Steam, 100% achievement)
[b]Grindy Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (2+ achievements that might take 10h+ to finish).
[b]Optional Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (~24 achievements).
[b]Difficult Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (~2 achievements).

[h1]Intro[/h1]
[i]Turbo Pug DX[/i] is a horrid game where you force an animal, usually a dog or a cat, to run through the world, avoiding cliffs and spikes that are coming to its way until it meets its inevitable fate - death. You'll become the cruelest people in the world and force thousands of animals to die without batting an eye. The game tries to hide this fact by masking it in an endless runner game with cute graphics and great music.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- 10 different animals to choose from with different jumping style
- You can replay the game quickly
- 2 minigames

[b]Cons:[/b]
- RNG-based deaths
- Minigames are pointless
- Some letters that are required to unlock minigames are very hard to find

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]To be honest, I don't see any reason to buy this game unless if you want to play a cheap endless runner with cute graphics and great music, which are the only main selling point of this game. There are a lot of free endless runner games on flash websites and the achievements for this game are too grindy to recommend. However, this game is still decent and cheap so I'm still recommending it for casual players who want to play it in short bursts.[/i]

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The game uses cute-looking sprites with beautiful, moving backgrounds. Some effects will be applied randomly to display the weather condition, whether it's snowing, raining, or sunny. An extra layer is also applied for day and night, which makes the presentation to be worthwhile.

[h1]The game[/h1]
[b]Characters[/b]
The game has 10 animals that you can choose from. Nine of them can be unlocked after you collect enough PugCoins, a collectible that you can obtain by playing the game. It might be hard to go for a high score with the basic pug, your starting animal, so you might want to try other animals that suit your playstyle. However, since you need to adjust your playstyle every time you change animals, you'll most likely end up sticking with one favorite animal to play with. 

[b]Endless Runner[/b]
Although it's an endless runner game, the game has two level sets that are repeated after another. The first level set lasts for 300 meters and has easy obstacle sets that you can avoid by jumping anytime you want. The second level set, the deadly one, will last for 500 meters and consists of a lot of difficult obstacle sets where you have to utilize your edge jump or remember the right timing of your jumps. Some jumps require precise timing, to the point that it feels cheap to die just because you are not jumping at the right pixel, especially with the basic pug.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2264530940 

Both level sets will randomly spawn their obstacle sets and change to the other level set once their time is up. There is no difference in running speed or anything, which makes it pointless to go further than 800 meters unless if you're aiming for achievements or leaderboards, which is broken to begin with. In fact, I even got bored after playing the game a few times and there's no way I'll stick playing the game for this long if not for the achievements and character unlocks.

The game is mostly an endurance run. You need to learn when to jump in every obstacle sets to reach a high score, provided that you're calm enough to play the game for a long time. Sometimes the game will give a variety by striking you with lightning, which will provide you immunity for a while. However, there is a certain spot that will give you an instant death if you were struck with it, making the game to be luck-based at times. Luckily, this doesn't happen very often.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2264530970

[b]Minigames[/b]
TURBOPUGDX letters will spawn in certain spots as you play the game. Collecting all letters will unlock a minigame in the next run, which gives nothing but an achievement and 500 PugCoins after you finish it. However, some letters, especially T and R, have a low spawning rate that you have to spend ~1h just to wait for them to show up.

There are 2 minigames that will be rotated right after another. Both minigames require you to do the same thing: focusing on two different tasks. However, I found that the second minigame to be harder than the first since you also need to guess whether you have to jump or not at certain times. Strangely, I felt more accomplished when I finished it compared to when I finished the 5000 meter run in the main game, which is also one of the hardest achievements in the game.

[b]Length[/b]
It took me 13.3h to finish the 5000m run and 19.4h to finish the second minigame. The playtime might vary based on your skill although you still need to grind for more hours to get the grindy achievements.

[h1]Specs[/h1]
Intel Core i5-9300H 2.40GHz, 8GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
It's an okay endless runner game with cute graphics and great music. Some harder obstacles might look cheap with a lot of edge jumps and small jump timing that you need to execute. You might also need to unlock other animals to get a high score because of how hard it is to play with the most basic pug. The game is just plain boring and I lost motivation after finishing the 5000m run, although the game is still okay because of the good-looking graphics.

74197601.review:
2.5 / 5.0

This is an endless type of side scrolling game where you try to get as far as possible all while collecting coins and bonus letters. Coins allow you to unlock new characters, letters allow you to play minigames. Unlocked characters have different physics, some run faster but jump is shorter, etc. This DX version has achievements and Steam trading cards vs. the old version of this game. 

This is a super easy game to pick up and play (basically a one-button jump game) but hard to master with increasing difficulty physics and levels the further you progress. For the price paid, this is a good game to have in the library for small sessions in-between longer games. Turbo Pug DX is a retro pixel 2D side scrolling endless runner/platformer where you control a cutesy pug (the main draw to the game, apparently) and must jump over obstacles to keep going.  Running into anything kills you.

This really is some of the worst kind of 2D retro pixel shovelware imaginable.  The game sells itself simply because the dog breed, pugs, exist, so I guess people think that would be a comical gimmick worth spending money on?  Trust me, it's not.  The game does work properly in 4K fullscreen thanks to the developers not mishandling Unity.  Controls are responsive but also unforgiving, which makes playing the game less than fun.   Ugly pixel graphics (the developers couldn't afford an artist) round out the thoroughly mediocre experience.   


Don't take my word for how bad this is... the community has spoken.   There's an achievment for dying the first time, and only 20% of the people who own the game have the achievement.

Turbo Pug DX, follows our cute little pug character and his friends through a platform of obstacles collecting coins, chests and other surprises. Players who like, or don’t mind 2D pixel runner games will enjoy the graphics it has to show. I also noticed an Easter egg, where the outdoors will shift from day/night time, depending on how long we play. I like how the game rewards players who survive longer too; whether unlocking a new landscape, achievements and more collectables for unlocking the rest of the crew! There’s also the nice addition of custom skins to choose from, though I never really was into them if it weren’t for the achievements. I haven’t tried the mini games and Jukebox yet, though, so no comment on those features yet. The audio and soundtracks suited the gameplay, with the latter being 8-bit music. 

The only minor issue it has is lack of tutorial and providing controls. (Then again, it is just a 1-key click game, and the goal is self-explanatory.)

The effects and animations all ran properly and smoothly during my gameplay. No bugs or glitches. That, along with the adorable cast of payable characters is enough for me to give this game a thumbs-up!

45620559.review:
Super cute game about pugs and one of my all time favourites!! :PugLove:

[b]The good👍[/b] 
👍Gameplay: It's an eternal runner. I'd say the difficulty is average/hard but fair, as in, when you lose you know why you died. You can also unlock more characters that control differently using the pug coins you collect. 

👍Controls: can be played on keyboard or mouse without problems, as you only need to hit space bar/click to jump.

👍Graphics: I think this is where the game truly shines. The pixel art is amazing, especially the characters sprites. It's also the most polished and pretty than in the previous games. The levels look much better and more varied too. 

👍Music: I would say it's good, fits well with the game.

👍Duration: It depends on your goals but as most runners the duration can be stretched as much as you want. It took me 3h to unlock all characters, but I didn't tried to beat the 1# highscore on the leader board, or get all the trophies, etc.

I think it's extremely good for its asking price and offers a lot. You can always wait for a sale (where it is super cheap) if you're hesitant. 

[b]The bad🙀[/b]
👎No Online Mode: it used to be a feature but got taken off due to people using programs to cheat on the learderboars and change scores. 

👎Trophies: with online mode taken off, it's impossible to get 100% completion because there's one trophy that requires you to play on-line, so Achievement Hunters be warned. All the other trophies can be obtained without any issues though.

44611770.review:
This game is bullshit.

In the first ten minutes of playtime, I got 8 out of the 9 letters. I'll get back to this.

The controls are awful, expecting precision while the controls have a latency of about half a second. That is to say, there is a noticeable delay between pressing space (or clicking) and the dog actually jumping. It's sluggish. This causes many unnecessary deaths. What makes I Wanna Be the Guy great is the fact that while it expects precision, the controls are tight as a motherfucker, so you learn to play with twitch reaction time. In this game, it's nearly impossible to predict what will happen when you jump. Sometimes, you even randomly get struck by lightning which freezes you in the air and gets you killed. That's not a joke. That actually happens.

The hit detection is awful. The jump with the crooked box is emblematic of everything that is wrong with it. You can land on top of it and still die. Nothing is consistent. You will die from things that didn't kill you the last time, even though you did it exactly the in same way. I've died several times just running over a straight block. How does THAT work?

After dying, the game makes you wait for about two full seconds before you can make another attempt. This is not telegraphed. It's just bad design. Again with IWBTG, you could restart instantly. There was no random latency.

This game is not fun. I stopped having fun ten minutes in.

The RNG is completely broken and full of **** (steam failed to censor me). Remember when I said that I made 99% of the progress in the first ten minutes? It's true. I got all the letters except for the 'T'. And then 10 more minutes passed. And then another 10 minutes passed, and before I knew it, I'd racked up an hour of playtime. 50 minutes without picking up a single T. Statistically, this is so improbable that you'd be as likely to win the lottery. If the RNG was working properly at all, then the T ought to have the same probability as all the other letters. There are nine letters: T,U,R,B,O,P,G,D,X. What is the probability of getting a T if the next letter is random? 1 in 9. After 17 letters in a row, what is the probability of NOT getting a T? 8 in 9. But with all 17 rounds considered together, that's twice the set length, the probability of not getting a T on the 18th letter is 8/9 * 8/9 * 8/9... = 12%. And after 34 letters, it's 1.8%. And after 150 letters it's 0.0000000021% (odds of winning the lottery: 0.0000000005%). Yet it somehow managed to continue to not appear despite collectively being on par with winning the fucking lottery. This is not random. Random is equally distributed. Good RNG emulates random by making all outputs of the function equally likely. 

This is not random. This is an insult to the player's intelligence. Don't waste your time or your money on this.

This game clearly overestimates how entertaining it is. It took 14 minutes of playing over and over again to reach the first unlockable--1k points, out of the 20k needed for the final unlockable--with fresh content that lasted 5 minutes at best. Die, die, and die again, this game is the epitome of repetition.

The input lag on the mouse made that unusable for jumping, and there was no controller support, so I had to resort to the space bar for the game and mouse for the menus. I appreciate what they tried to do with the procedural generation of the tracks, piecing together different paths with different seasons,  times of day and music, but there just isn't enough variation for that to remain interesting for long. The dull gameplay remains the same throughout: jump. Jump over the blocks, jump into the "coins"; that's it. And the first unlockable isn't even worth it, requiring you to press jump twice to survive what only took one before, often not leaving you with enough time to react. Die with 70 points, rinse, and repeat until you hit the next thousand.

I was bored well before 14 minutes in, and I had seen all of the core content within the first 5. The art is nice, the music is nice, but the mechanics are so bare-bones as to be an asset pack's example level. I got this game for free, and frankly that's all it's worth. It's a high-quality free game, but should be free nonetheless.

I would give this game a 2/10.

I will start out by saying there are some positives to this game: decent enough graphics, music is not the worst thing ever, and unlockables. Plus the game is only a dollar, so that's nice I guess.

However,

There are three serious issues with this game. First, there are some bad hitboxes that leave you feeling frustrated and disatisfied half of the time that you die. Second, half of the characters (the first half) seem to have really unresponsive jumping times, which makes the game very not fun because dying repeatedly because of terrible mechanics is cheap and unfair. Third, there are letters which need to be collected to unlock minigames (which have achievements if you win), but it takes way too long to collect all the letters for minigames which you often fail in the first 20 seconds of playing. The developer somehow completely butchered the spawning algorithm for the letters so that u's appear every other letter, at the least, whereas other letters will randomly not appear for 20 minutes at a time.

These issues could have been fixed incredibly easy. The bad hitbox is manageable with the later characters who have less crap jumping mechanics, but there is no reason to force the player to sit through an hour+ of bad mechanics for a 1 dollar game. As for the letters, there are so many options:

1) Fix the algorithm and make the letters you don't have yet appear more frequently.
2) Just fix the u's to not appear so much.
3) Create a shop where you can spend pugpoints on extra letters.

Instead there is this system where players can play for 4 hours and only attempt the minigames for a total of 9 times.

As much fun as it would be to mindlessly "play" for another hour to try the minigames another 2 times, I think I am done with this game.

41358086.review:
I'm gonna level with you and tell you that I bought this like 50% for the name and 50% for the aesthetic.  I'm not even a big fan of the genre.  Yet somehow even dropping a forgettable 50 cents on this game has left me with the tiniest bit of buyers remorse.  Not because the name lied or the pugs aren't real, but because it misses the main point of the runner genre.

[h1]Rewarding the Runner[/h1]

The only reason runner games exist, as far as I can tell, is because they offer a steady stream of reward for playing.  Whether it's more maneuvering, going faster, surviving hits, or just simply cosmetic stuff, you're being fed positive reinforcement to give you a reason to keep playing.  Turbo Pug DX seems to do the opposite.  You're tasked with collecting a bunch of objects that give you varying amounts of a currency that very slowly unlocks new characters for you to use in the game.   This seemingly doesn't pick up much speed since after I unlocked a first character after maybe 5-10 minutes of playing, I had to grind through another 20-30 minutes to unlock the second.  I have no idea how far the third will be and I just don't want to find out.   Runners are inherently not fun enough to keep people playing beyond short sessions.  They're usually set up to be repetitive and simple to occupy short periods on people's phones.  Here, I'm stuck slogging through a barebones runner design with nothing but more of the same to look forward to.

The only other reward aspect is that you have to collect the letters that comprise the title of the game (TURBO PUG DX) similar to the way you would in a collect-a-thon 3D platformer or a Tony Hawk game.  Collecting all of these lets you start the next round in a mini game.  However, you get one shot at this mini game, and the instructions presented for it barely give you an idea for what you're about to encounter.  The first time, I was presented with a timed event of stopping changing letters (spelling out the title again) while simultaneously continuing the runner gameplay.  I ran out of time and was forced to collect the letters in the main game again.  The problem with this is that it throws the letters at you in a totally random way, so I had to grab the same ones seemingly dozens of times waiting for the last one or two I needed to appear.  Then, when I finally got back to the minigame, it was an entirely new  setup where I failed literally within seconds because I had no idea I'd be attacked from behind.  Besides, why would I?  Runners are always designed to have all threats come from in front of you... but I guess that's just not how things work here.

[h1]What little remains[/h1]

There's no reason to really write more about Turbo Pug DX.  It's just simply not fun to play.  It does have some cool music, but it quickly gets repetitive since you only hear three or four of the many songs available (you can hear them all in the jukebox part of the menu).  I'm not sure why they wouldn't cycle all of the songs as you play, but that's just another entry on the list of disappointing choices made for this game.  Save your dollar or half dollar if it's on sale.   You could spend it on Steam trading cards and probably get better value.

Remember FlappyBird? This is very similar in term of its simplicity played with one mouse button, its difficulty, and the frustration that it causes the player. There are certainly differences between the two games, this one has adorable graphics, more character options that you get to unlock as you play, and the music is much better.

I got this game for free, and I thought I would give it a go, well, a few short hours later, I have to say, it's rather addictive too. 

Pros:
+Graphics
+Music, but it can get repetitive after a while
+Simplicity
+Addicting and Fun--for the right person
+Different playable characters with different abilities
+Customization possible for level design with presets available 

Cons:
-Hit boxes are not always consistent
-Variety in the levels could be more diverse (I have not made it very far, my highest score is about 390, but I start seeing different level designs start popping up after 250 that does not show up before. I wish it is just completely random with all options possible starting at the very beginning)
-Leaderboards worked for me the first time I played, has not been able to load last couple of times I fired up the game.

Neutral:
-Difficulty--it was never meant to be an easy game
-Minigames--Good variety, but so difficult! I wish the minigames were available continually after you unlock them the first time, but you have to keep unlocking them, and I do not last very long in those.It's not too difficult to unlock, but I just want to be able to play it more than once every 15-20 minutes.

Conclusion:
Got the game for free, can't complain. Fun and addicting game. It's a dollar at normal price, so for those who enjoyed torturing themselves with FlappyBird, this is not a bad alternative. It is not as difficult. Not a game for everyone, but I am having a good time with it.

41139282.review:
[h1]Turbo Pug DX: Un juego para pasar el rato.[/h1]

[b]Es difícil hacer un análisis sobre este tipo de juegos dada la sencillez del mismo, pero voy a tratar de ser lo más completo posible dentro de las posibilidades que tengo.[/b]

Turbo Pug DX es un juego donde solo corremos y recolectamos objetos: Monedas (Representadas por el rostro de un pug), regalos (que dan entre 5 y 50 monedas) y letras, las cuales se usan para formar TURBOPUGDX.

El juego no tiene un sistema de niveles, simplemente es correr, morir, reiniciar, no hay una meta real, solo conseguir mayor cantidad de monedas y hacer un recorrido mayor para superar tu mejor marca.

Hay diferentes personajes que a su vez ofrecen distintas “ventajas” (como doble salto o mayor velocidad), para desbloquearlos se requiere superar una cantidad determinada de monedas, el error del juego es no decirte cuántas de estas necesitas para cada personaje y qué ventajas te ofrece. Simplemente juegas hasta que aparece un nuevo personaje, si no lo pruebas, no sabes qué beneficio obtendremos por usarlo, un error de resolución simple que no fue reparado.

Otro punto negativo son los logros, algunos de los cuales son a groso modo ABSURDOS, morir 2000 veces o superar distancias enormes no son logros que apetezcan conseguirse, son una molestia para los jugadores, sin lógica y dado lo repetitivo del juego, la gran mayoría no los conseguirá nunca.

Otro tema son los niveles especiales, que se consiguen de forma automática al formal la palabra TURBOPUGDX con las letras que recolectas durante tus carreras, no son difíciles y agregan algo diferente al juego, pero obtener las letras puede llegar a costarte entre 10 y 50 carreras dependiendo la suerte que tengas, con un juego de generación aleatoria, las mismas se repiten y encontrar las últimas que se necesitan puede llevar mucho tiempo, lo que termina aburriendo al jugador.

[b] PROS: [/b]

+  Juego Barato, con requerimientos mínimos y poco consumo de disco.
+  Entretenido para pasar un rato.
+  Facil de entender, facil de controlar.
+  Buen trabajo gráfico y de sonido.

[b] CONTRAS: [/b]
- Extremadamente repetitivo.
- Pobremente ejecutado el sistema de personajes, sin información de cómo desbloquearlos y qué ventajas ofrecen.
- Logros absurdos, de poca probabilidad de obtención.

Turbo Pug DX is a fun, easy to play platform game. 💖

You can give your pug their own name, along with a custom skin, as well as unlocking skins/characters (such as a turtle or kitten) later in the game. Unlocked characters each have their own characteristics, and special skills. Unlocking characters and earning achievements are mainly linked to earning enough pug coins, the 'points' or 'currency' (albeit one you can't 'spend'!) in the game. 

Did I mention how cute the game is? The art style is terrific, very colorful and bright, which makes a change from the hours I've spent on the grim and somber, Evil Within. The only aspect of the game that could be classes as horror is the music; 'chip tune', it's not for everyone. 

At least for me, the game has triggered severe motion sickness, so I can't comment on it's replay value. However I can say that the 'runs' seem quite diverse, changes happening to the level/map each time your pug dies. There's elements of the old mixed in with the new: tricky jumps, lava filled pits, and all. (PS: Chests and star buttons are filled with collectibles! Tree stumps, vases, and snowmen won't hurt you, they're part of the background. Don't be fooled!)

There's tallies kept of your highest score, current score, and your total score, as well as leader boards. You can challenge yourself or play the game to relax - Pug Turbo DX can be the platform/runner game you want it to be: a challenging game or a simple, cute one. 

Or both! -:) 

PPS: It has adorable badges to display (including a hamster!), as well as cute emojis, backgrounds, and achievements. How can anyone resist a pug in a sombrero?

Full review posted on: http://www.pingaling.co/my-reviews.html

TurboPug DX is a raucus emotional rollercoaster that is filled to the brim with lingering leftys and righteous rightys. After completing this game, it feels like you were just beaten up by Little Mac, from Mike Tyson's PunchOut. Sure, you could say it feels like you just got beat up by Mike Tyson, but even HE couldn't beat Little Mac. TurboPug DX is a game that leaves you thinking about it's philosophy for hours, even after you've already beaten the game. From the first time your pug charges head first into a spike at terminal velocity, or you gaze upon the flowing cape of a pug with a santa hat, this game proves itself to be different from the others. TurboPug DX has 27 achievements, and after the game has been completed, the prophecy fufilled, the saddest shit on earth happens: Man Tears. Similar to Spam, Ham in a Can, You don't really play TurboPug DX, you experience it. TurboPug's strict learning curve and the complete lack of both gravity and physics, coupled with the fact that TurboPug DX doesn't even follow it's own rules, all strung up with a wide variety of 2 bullshit minigames makes TurboPug DX an experience to remember. TurboPug DX has forged a special place in my heart. It pulled me out of a dark place, and brought me to finally see and accept the Great Pug in the Sky, and through His guidance ('a' from the TurboPug DX leaderboard) we can all accept TurboPug DX for what it truly is: the greatest experience on TurboPug's green Earth itself.
Infinity/10

40961580.review:
A runner....

Not that this type of game genre is bad, but lets just say noone of these kind of games should be a PC game - it should stay on mobile devices.

TurboPugDX is such a game - very repetitive and frustrating.

You start off as a doggy that has to run.... far?! i guess?! .... for some reason?! -well yea he has to run.
Pre-made obstacles are randomly set after each other where as some are even impossible to be beaten because you e.g. need a doublejump or your pet has to have a lower speed because otherwise you'd hit a box.
There is not much of a variety and sometimes they repeat each other.

The only variety in a run is the weather - it randomly changes in seconds and does not do anything but fill up your screen or lower the brightness. Sometimes when its stormy you get hit by a thunder and skip 2-3 obstacles tho most of the times it killes you because you can not jump for a brief moment after it.

On your way there are "Pug Points" to be collected that do nothing else but unlock new pets that sometimes have different abilites such as faster movement speed. They dont help you in getting any further tho.

Also you can collect letters that if you have all of them form the word "TubopugsDX", sometimes it takes ages for the last letter to appear.
When you have all of them, in your next run you have to play a minigame, at least thats what it says. 2 are available and chosen after each other. They are your classic endless running and at the same time doing something else but...sadly both dont introduce you to anything and just throw you right in so that you die instantly. In 4h of playing this game i never had more than 10seconds of a minigame and just instatly died. I dont even know what they give you as a reward ,how long you play them or what you are supposed to do.

After all in 4 hours of playing i never got further than 430meters where as in other simillar games im quite good. This is because of the uncontrolable controlls and bad hitboxes than sometimes just randomly kill you, not to mention impossible obstacles.

You can change the skin of your obstacles with some fanmade ones or create your own (very complicated with photoshop) but the way the obstacles are set are still the same premade ones.

Only the music and artstyle is quite nice but this still is no reason to play this very bad mobile port runner game.
Dont ever pay for that.

Tags: Casual - Runner

TLDR: Marginally improved engine and online skins integrated in menu are interesting. Progression using pugcoins seems less well handled than original. Repetitive and played out.

Other than the TLDR info, I've noticed that not unlocking skins or songs through play affected the addictiveness and longevity of the title quite a bit for me. Collecting letters for the hidden level was not very engaging either since the hidden level had you use KB+M for the gimmick and this game is best played with a controller. 

The controls did not feel terribly sharp and the procedural level design will stonewall you with rather BS obstacles on a regular basis.

There are some interesting runner types like Olli Olli which allows trickmoves or the legendary bit trip runner for example, there are runners with multiplayer like Speedrunners. This is really bottom tier in comparison.

40877463.review:
Pulsar la tecla espacio, habilidad y paciencia, es lo único que se necesita para jugar.

Es un juego tipo correr en una sola dirección, donde será clave pulsar en el momento adecuado para ir esquivando todos los objetos que te encuentras por el camino. Simple y para jugadores casuales. 

El objetivo según he podido comprobar en el tiempo que he jugado, es recoger todas las letras de la palabra "Turbopugdx" que te encuentras por el escenario, así como caritas de perros, cajas o cofres para ir sumando puntos en el global. Puntos que no se te reinician tras fallar. Se acumulan conforme vuelves y vuelves a jugar el escenario tras los sucesivos errores.

Las letras están siempre en la misma posición del escenario, pero van rotando de forma aleatoria cada vez que lo intentas. Por lo que es posible, conseguir todas las letras sin tener que llegar a zonas nuevas. Ademas, cuando se reinicia el juego cada vez que te chocas, empiezas por una parte completamente diferente. La música, adictiva, también cambia.

Cuando se consiguen todas las letras, salta una fase bonus. Acabada esta, vuelta a empezar de nuevo para conseguir una vez mas, todas las letras de la palabra Turbopugdx.

Los gráficos están muy bien cuidados, estilo pixel, teniendo incluso climatología cambiante. La música es pegadiza y acompaña. 
Dentro del menú, tienes una tabla con las mejores puntuaciones hechas por los jugadores, perros desbloqueables (saltan mas, menos, tienen un estilo diferente) y skins para cambiar por completo la forma de ver de los escenarios. En la pagina de steam, aparece como que tiene editor de niveles, pero no es cierto. Y es un fallo grave en este tupo de juegos.

Me ha salido completamente gratis. Lo recomendaría estando en oferta a un precio inferior a 0,99, ya que por ese mismo precio, tienes alternativas mucho mejores como "Geometry Dash" (que suelen rebajarlo a esa cifra en ofertas). Aun así, merece una oportunidad si te gustan este tipo de juegos.

37978957.review:
[b]The Basic concept of the game[/b]
Turbo Pug DX is about you playing as a pug running in a fast paced jump timing game.

[b] GamePlay [/b]
The gameplay for this game is very simple as all you have to jump over objects while getting the coins to unlock new pugs and dogs the only control is space bar ,if anyone would like to know. while the gameplay is very simple its a fun game to pass the time. The longer your run for the harder the game gets as it will become faster and therefore harder to time the jumps. The different pugs/dogs in this game have different types of jumps that makes each pug have its benefits and drawbacks. This makes the game a lot more fun as when you unlock a new pug there will be a new learning curve for you to learn. This add more to the gameplay.

[b] Price [/b]
The cost to get this game is very fair and i do recommend to pick this game up if you have some money on your steam wallet that you won't be using. Its not a game that you will be playing for hours at a time but its a game you will like to come back to and try to get a better score. Thats why the price of 1 euro for this game is a good deal.

[b] Graphics/level design [/b]
The graphics are very simple for this game just like the gameplay is. It has a simple pixel graphics artwork that works well for this game. What i like about this game is that you can choose how the level looks as you have the option to change the level deign for this game e.g halloween theme.

[b] Overall [/b]
I think this game is worth getting as the price for this game is fair and its quite a fun game to play when you have free time. I dont see people playing this game a lot in one run but its a fun game to come back to and see if you can try to beat your high score. This game is worth buying at its price.

[b] Thanks HellCow [/b]

34828846.review:
[h1]Turbo Pug DX [/h1]
-------------- 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]- The gameplay is compromised of a very basic side scrolling element, which most of us associate as being very tedious and boring. Except for in this game they've made it very charming and easy to see past. Although from time to time, it does feel clunky when playing with keyboard & mouse. I definitely reccomend using a controller for the best experience possibe.

[h1]Art Direction[/h1]- The game, for being what it is, has a very detailed pixel art design which nicely complements its sound track and gameplay. 

[h1]Soundtrack[/h1]- Out of all the variables, ranging from character selection to gameplay, the soundtrack has to be my very favorite part of this game. It is so diverse and easy on the ears. Every course has a different and unique sound that takes away and adds to many genres extremely well. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]- Turbo Pug DX looks like a title you get just for the trading cards. From first glance it looks like something that would just sit at the bottom of your library and you would never think of touching it. I know, because it sat in my library for months before I decided to play it. For a title so inexpensive I definitely am happy I gave it a try. Overall it's a nice, satisfying time sink.

34571386.review:
In this game, you play as a pug (or other unlockable animals) and run and jump over obstacles.   It starts off "Nintendo hard" for several hours, but you get better as you continue.  PROTIP: you don't need to double jump nearly as much as you think you do.  If you're good, this game will take about 25 hours to 100%.  One of the achievements depends on how long your pug has run and it will take about 25 hours to do this.  My suggestion is to play the game while you're watching TV or listening to YouTube videos or whathaveyou.  

Someone can correct me if I'm wrong, but there's really only 1 stage and it keeps going endlessly until you crash into something.  Throughout the stage, the placement of obstacles may change so it's not always exactly the same each time you play.  You can also apply other "skins" to the level and there are also weather changes and day/night changes in the background.

Should you get this game?  I say yes.  It's only 99 cents and sometimes you can find it marked down to 49 cents.  The characters are cute.  However, most people will not 100% this game due to the difficulty.

30964108.review:
I liked the first Turbo Pug game, so I thought I would give this one a shot too. I definitely prefer the original to this, mainly because it was so much more simple and I feel like Turbo Pug DX added a lot of (what seemed like) interesting features to it that just aren't necessary. 

I liked having the pug coins unlock new playable characters, but it just kind of bothers me that after collecting everyone the coins do nothing... I think being able to buy more customizable items or powerups would have been pretty cool. (Maybe eventually??)

My other issue is that it seems like the game lags a bit sometimes, but usually for me, it's worse on my first play and after that, it smooths out a bit. I think that there's very little leeway when it comes to avoiding obstacles... but that's probably just me being terrible at this game! c: 

Having achievements to reach is nice, despite needing to commit several hours to the game to get them.

The last thing- pretty much my only real issue with the game- is the changing colors in the background. It may just be me being old and having issues with my eyesight, but sometimes I struggle seeing where the pug is compared to obstacles and boxes that I need to jump over and onto. Using a custom BG helps a lot, so if you decide to play and have this problem, I definitely recommend doing that in the options setting.

If you don't like casual, simple games, you probably won't like this game. But if you're like me and play games to kill some time, you'll probably enjoy Turbo Pug DX.

30746373.review:
[h1]Summary:[/h1] [b]Unresponsive Suicidal Pug[/b]

[h1]Quick Personal Overview:[/h1] [b](I see that a lot of people liked it, so just go for it I suppose.)[/b]
The game has potential but it's rather bland for a Runner game, personally I'm used to Runner games with PowerUps and such to keep things interesting, and I always had a distaste for "vanilla" Runners like this one. On top of that the game is considerably [b]unresponsive[/b], sometimes when you want to perfom a consecutive jump, as in Jump > Land > Quickly Jump again, the "trucker" won't respond and you'll end up dying...a lot because of this. [u]Other than that all I can say it's just another Runner game, nothing special to it.[/u]

[h1]Personal Experience:[/h1] Horrible, since like I stated before I feel it's a bland game and I'm a completionist "truck". I got all the Achievements in about 3-4 hours, except for 2000 Deaths and 500km Run. So being forced to play this game for rougthly 14-16 EXTRA hours due to the last two achievements is just idiotic. I simply don't understand why would they place such extremely time consuming Achievements to such a stupid game; not even Shantae a perfect example of a good indie game with relatively hard Achievements, requires you to sink in so many hours into it.

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1] Anyone who bothered reading this, will probably say I'm just "hitching" and giving it a negative review simply because the Achievements, which I am to blame for forcing myself to go through them. [u]But in reality the unresponsiveness and blandness make it a bad experience overall.[/u]

29436626.review:
(This game's review is brought to you courtesy of Spookymcslave's donation.  Thanks, man!)

Please ignore the time put into this game.  There are massive grinds for achievements in this game...

[i]Turbo Pug DX[/i] is a very frustrating runner game created in Unity...and it's the 2nd runner I've played involving a dog (the first being [i]Montaro[/i], who is playable in this game as well.)  As like with many runners, you die...often.  The music will be burned into the depths of your mind as you grow increasingly frustrated from constant failures.

If you get enough letter pickups, you unlock ONE CHANCE at a minigame to play.  Learn it fast, because if you don't, you're dead.  If you want to replay the same event, you must get all the letter pickups two more times.   Why 2 more times?  Because the game is set to put the two minigames in rotation.  If you've beaten one and only want to play the other, you must trigger the minigame you want by only reaching the minigame you don't want to play.  If that's not bad enough, you often get repeat letters you don't want.  Example:  "U, U, U, X, U, U, P, U, U, U, U, G, U, U, X, U, O, X, P, U, U"  (That's recorded from a single run of actual gameplay)

There appears to be a visual error where "coin" pickups (which unlock character skins, a few with a different playstyle) can either be picked up twice by being touched once, or they simply don't appear (the latter is true of chests, which grant 5 "coins").  You'll find coins to be absolutely worthless when you unlock the last character.  There's also a questionable hitbox when it comes to certain areas and certain characters (much like the final character you unlock).

But not everything in [i]Turbo Pug DX[/i] is bad.  The game's visuals are pretty good and the programming for the section randomizer is pretty well-done (though some areas will get repetitive and you'll find areas that are devoid of letter pickups...some balancing is in order).


Is it worth your money?  Although it looks good, my experience leads to a disappointing "no".  For the same money, you'll be better off with [i]Montaro[/i] (which has schoolgirls and pantsu).  I can't stop you from making your purchase, but if you value your sanity and don't enjoy a stressful experience of frustration and hair-tearing frustration...you might want to think twice.  It's not a BAD game...I just don't recommend it due to the stress it induced.

2/10  A very frustrating runner involving a pug and other animals.

26083998.review:
[Full disclosure: My copy of Turbopug DX was supplied by www.pcgamesnnews.wordpress.com]

Endless runners typically have two extremes when it comes to quality: One end of the spectrum being addictive and enjoyable to play for hours on end while the other end runs it course and becomes dull and drab before long. Turbopug DX mostly certainly falls into the latter category while also suffering from being just not fun to play. It’s cute motif and deceptively alright soundtrack may be attractive to some along with its low price, but there are certainly much better games of this genre out there.

Turbopug DX follows the typical formula as other endless runners in which your character moves forward constantly and must avoid obstacles while gathering collectibles and going for a high score. Said collectibles come in the form of letters that spells out ‘Turbopug DX’ along with pug tokens that come in counts of one, five and twenty five which goes towards unlocking new types of pugs and animals to play as - This is all simple stuff that gives the game something to work towards while going for high scores, but unfortunately it falls apart when you actually start playing the game. To start, even with the game being controllable with a single button, I encountered many instances where my input would be eaten upon having my pug land on the ground and try to jump again immediately, like I had to wait for my jump to ‘cool down’ for a fleeting moment. This had runs frequently be robbed from me since the game runs rather quickly and requires jumps with tricky timing that need to be strung together, and often require the right landing otherwise your jump will be too early or too late and your pug will run headfirst into an obstacle. Jumping simply doesn’t feel good because of the game’s speed, with very little hang time once airborne before your pug plummets like a stone in water.

The overall issue with Turbopug DX however is that it simply becomes dull and painfully repetitive after twenty minutes once the cute charm has worn off. The level proceeds with obstacle ‘sets’, but these sets are limited and any sense of surprise is brief, making the game feel awfully stale in no time. The game does cycle between visual styles and even has a whole system to create, share and play with custom skins that are applied over the level, but that can only go so far when the game itself becomes boring and artificial means have to be used in order to freshen things up. Collecting letters to spell out the title of the game does let you play a minigame as a change of pace, but the issues here are twofold: For one, collecting those letters is based off of lucky spawn rates which means that when you’re missing one or two letters you’ll run into repeats more often than not, and split paths in the level can make you miss a needed one. Secondly, failing the minigame once kicks you back to the main menu and you have to collecting all the letters again to have another shot - Completing these minigames grants achievements, so by that margin it’s really not worth the hassle.

Even with a peppy soundtrack, very little saves Turbopug DX from being a cheap yet painfully drab experience. The cute aesthetic is strangely subverted with the fact that your pug can die, not limited to spikes and sawblades that have blood coating some of them - And that’s on the default visual skin. The game is $1.09 (Canadian) so purchasing it will certainly not break the bank, but considering how there are endless runner games on mobile platforms for free that’re better than this, there’s no way I can recommend Turbopug DX unless you’re a fanatic for pugs, endless runner or score attack games - Even then, this one is a hard sell due to being far too generic.

To me a few things are important for the simple one-button endless runners.
1. Perfect Controls

2. Smooth Scrolling
In Turbo Pug it gets blurry, makeing it hard to watch to long
3. Fair collision - Even if I do not land perfectly or when jumping I touch the top of the obstacle a bit, a game should accept that.
Turbo Pug is not. It feels like a prototype implementation. Just simple "collision -> dead"
4. Flow
Turbo Pug, especially due to the first three points does not allow me to get into a flow.
